We are given two Java programs that are meant to be executed in sequence. The output of the first program is the input to the second. First program (atcoder_ABC108_B):
  - Reads four integers: x1, y1, x2, y2.
  - Computes two more points (x3, y3) and (x4, y4) such that:
        (x3, y3) = revpos((x1,y1), (x2,y2))
        (x4, y4) = revpos((x2,y2), (x3,y3))
  - Then it checks if (x1,y1) is the same as revpos((x3,y3), (x4,y4))? (but note: in Java, array == is reference equality, so this check is broken. However, in the problem we don't rely on that check for output because we always output the computed points)
  - Outputs the four integers: x3, y3, x4, y4 (each on a new line)

Second program (atcoder_ABC114_C):
  - Reads an integer N.
  - Counts numbers that are <= N, composed only of digits 3,5,7 and contain each of 3,5,7 at least once.
